thread.title: Australian share market slides 1.5pc at open following wild swings on Wall Street
thread.title_full: Australian share market slides 1.5pc at open following wild swings on Wall Street

author: MITCHELL NEEMS
title: Australian share market slides 1.5pc at open following wild swings on Wall Street
text:
THE Australian stockmarket has lost ground today after a wild swing in late trading saw Wall Street close weaker for the sixth straight session.
Early this afternoon, the benchmark ASX 200 index was down 0.9 per cent at about 5090 points.
Earlier, it had fallen 81.2 points, or 1.6 per cent, to 5056.1 points, while the broader All Ordinaries retreated 77.3 points, or 1.5 per cent, to 5066.5 points.
CMC chief market analyst Ric Spooner said that against a background of ongoing volatility and large market swings, investors were unsettled by the fact that US markets gave up early large gains to finish down last night.
“The Australian market, which staged a strong rally has potentially been wrong footed by this move, at least to begin with,” he said.
He added that the positive impact of China’s announced interest and reserve ratio cut proved to be short lived.
“The weakness in US stocks last night also hints that the fact that this downturn is about more than just a reassessment of China’s growth outlook.”
Overnight, both the Dow Jones Industrial Average and the S&P 500 slipped closed more than 1 per cent lower.
This was despite US stocks being 2 per cent higher just an hour out from the end of trade. At one point during the session Wall Street was more than 2.5 per cent in the black.
“It’s now some time since the US stock market has had a major correction. This makes it vulnerable to volatility once some large moves have started and markets are concerned that it could take some time for things to settle down,” Mr Spooner said.
Locally, in economic news today, Reserve Bank governor Glenn Stevens is slated to speak at the National Reform Summit.
The Australian Bureau of Statistics releases quarterly construction work figures.
In equities news, Seven Group, Westfield Corporation, BC Iron and WorleyParsons all release financial results.
The local market yesterday posted its strongest gains in almost four years in a remarkable turnaround from Monday's $64 billion plunge.
The benchmark ASX 200 index was up 136 points, or 2.7 per cent, at 5137.3 points.
The broader All Ordinaries index was up 129.6 points, or 2.58 per cent, at 5143.8 points.
Originally published as Aussie stocks slide after wild Wall St ride
